Private Heterogeneous Federated Learning Without a Trusted Server Revisited: Error-Optimal and Communication-Efficient Algorithms for Convex Losses

Changyu Gao∗,1, Andrew Lowy∗,1, Xingyu Zhou∗,2, Stephen J. Wright1
1University of Wisconsin-Madison, 2Wayne State University
††Equal Contribution. Correspondence to Changyu Gao ¡changyu.gao@wisc.edu¿, Andrew Lowy ¡alowy@wisc.edu¿
Abstract

We revisit the problem of federated learning (FL) with private data from people who do not trust the server or other silos/clients. In this context, every silo (e.g. hospital) has data from several people (e.g. patients) and needs to protect the privacy of each person’s data (e.g. health records), even if the server and/or other silos try to uncover this data. Inter-Silo Record-Level Differential Privacy (ISRL-DP) prevents each silo’s data from being leaked, by requiring that silo i𝑖i’s communications satisfy item-level differential privacy. Prior work (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b) characterized the optimal excess risk bounds for ISRL-DP algorithms with homogeneous (i.i.d.) silo data and convex loss functions. However, two important questions were left open: (1) Can the same excess risk bounds be achieved with heterogeneous (non-i.i.d.) silo data? (2) Can the optimal risk bounds be achieved with fewer communication rounds? In this paper, we give positive answers to both questions. We provide novel ISRL-DP FL algorithms that achieve the optimal excess risk bounds in the presence of heterogeneous silo data. Moreover, our algorithms are more communication-efficient than the prior state-of-the-art. For smooth loss functions, our algorithm achieves the optimal excess risk bound and has communication complexity that matches the non-private lower bound. Additionally, our algorithms are more computationally efficient than the previous state-of-the-art.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning paradigm in which multiple silos (a.k.a. clients), such as hospitals or cell-phone users, collaborate to train a global model. In FL, silos store their data locally and exchange focused updates (e.g. stochastic gradients), sometimes making use of a central server (Kairouz et al., 2021). FL has been applied in myriad domains, from consumer digital products (e.g. Google’s mobile keyboard (Hard et al., 2018) and Apple’s iOS (Apple, 2019)) to healthcare (Courtiol et al., 2019), finance (FedAI, 2019), and large language models (LLMs) (Hilmkil et al., 2021).

One of the primary reasons for the introduction of FL was to enhance protection of the privacy of people’s data (McMahan et al., 2017). Unfortunately, local storage is not sufficient to prevent data from being leaked, because the model parameters and updates communicated between the silos and the central server can reveal sensitive information (Zhu and Han, 2020; Gupta et al., 2022). For example, Gupta et al. (2022) attacked a FL model for training LLMs to uncover private text data.

Differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2006) guarantees that private data cannot be leaked. Different variations of DP have been considered for FL. Central DP prevents the final trained FL model from leaking data to an external adversary (Jayaraman and Wang, 2018; Noble et al., 2022). However, central DP has two major drawbacks: (1) it does not provide a privacy guarantee for each individual silo; and (2) it does not ensure privacy when an attacker/eavesdropper has access to the server or to another silo.

Another notion of DP for FL is user-level DP (McMahan et al., 2018; Geyer et al., 2017; Levy et al., 2021). User-level DP mitigates the drawback (1) of central DP, by providing privacy for the complete local data set of each silo. User-level DP is practical in the cross-device FL setting, where each silo is a single person (e.g. cell-phone user) with a large number of records (e.g. text messages). However, user-level DP still permits privacy breaches if an adversary has access to the server or eavesdrops on the communications between silos. Moreover, user-level DP is not well-suited for cross-silo federated learning, where silos represent organizations like hospitals, banks, or schools that house data from many individuals (e.g. patients, customers, or students). In the cross-silo FL context, each person possesses a record, referred to as an “item,” which may include sensitive data. Therefore, an appropriate notion of DP for cross-silo FL should safeguard the privacy of each individual record (i.e. “item-level differential privacy”) within silo i𝑖i, rather than the complete aggregated data of silo i𝑖i.

Following Lowy et al. (2023a); Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b); Liu et al. (2022) (among others), this work considers inter-silo record-level DP (ISRL-DP). ISRL-DP requires that the full transcript of messages sent by silo i𝑖i satisfy item-level DP, for all silos i𝑖i. Thus, ISRL-DP guarantees the privacy of each silo’s local data, even in the presence of an adversary with access to the server, other silos, or the communication channels between silos and the server. See Figure 1 for an illustration. If each silo only has one record, then ISRL-DP reduces to local DP (Kasiviswanathan et al., 2011; Duchi et al., 2013). However, in the FL setting where each silo has many records, ISRL-DP FL is more appropriate and permits much higher accuracy than local DP (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b). Moreover, ISRL-DP implies user-level DP if the ISRL-DP parameters are sufficiently small (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b). Thus, ISRL-DP is a practical privacy notion for cross-silo and cross-device FL when individuals do not trust the server or other silos/clients/devices with their sensitive data.

Problem Setup.

Consider a FL environment with N𝑁N silos, where each silo has a local data set with n𝑛n samples: Xi=(xi,1,⋯,xi,n)subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1⋯subscript𝑥𝑖𝑛X_{i}=(x_{i,1},\cdots,x_{i,n}) for i∈[N]:={1,…,N}𝑖delimited-[]𝑁assign1…𝑁i\in[N]:=\{1,\ldots,N\}. At the beginning of every communication round r𝑟r, silos receive the global model wrsubscript𝑤𝑟w_{r}. Silos then utilize their local data to enhance the model, and send local updates to the server (or to other silos for peer-to-peer FL). The server (or other silos) uses the local silo updates to update the global model.

For each silo i𝑖i, let 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} be an unknown probability distribution on a data domain 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Let f:𝒲×𝒳→ℝ:𝑓→𝒲𝒳ℝf:\mathcal{W}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} be a loss function (e.g. cross-entropy loss for logistic regression), where 𝒲⊂ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{W}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is a parameter domain. Assume f​(⋅,x)𝑓⋅𝑥f(\cdot,x) is convex. Silo i𝑖i’s local objective is to minimize its expected population/test loss, which is

Fi​(w):=𝔼xi∼𝒟i​[f​(w,xi)].assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑤subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]𝑓𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖F_{i}(w):=\mathbb{E}_{x_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}[f(w,x_{i})]. (1)

Our (global) objective is to find a model that achieves small error for all silos, by solving the FL problem

minw∈𝒲⁡{F​(w):=1N​∑i=1NFi​(w)},subscript𝑤𝒲assign𝐹𝑤1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤\min_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\left\{F(w):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(w)\right\}, (FL)

while maintaining the privacy of each silo’s local data under ISRL-DP.

Assume that the samples {xi,j}i∈[N],j∈[n]subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑁𝑗delimited-[]𝑛\{x_{i,j}\}_{i\in[N],j\in[n]} are independent. The FL problem is homogeneous if the data is i.i.d., i.e., 𝒟i=𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{i}=\mathcal{D}_{j} for all i,j∈[N]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁i,j\in[N]. In this work, we focus on the more challenging heterogeneous (non-i.i.d.) case: i.e. the data distributions {𝒟i}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑖1𝑁\{\mathcal{D}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N} may be arbitrary. This case arises in many practical FL settings (Kairouz et al., 2021).

Contributions.

The quality of a private algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} for solving Problem FL is measured by its excess risk (a.k.a. excess population/test loss), 𝔼​[F​(𝒜​(𝐗))]−F∗𝔼delimited-[]𝐹𝒜𝐗superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X}))]-F^{*}, where F∗=infw∈𝒲F​(w)superscript𝐹subscriptinfimum𝑤𝒲𝐹𝑤F^{*}=\inf_{w\in\mathcal{W}}F(w) and the expectation is over the random draw of the data 𝐗=(X1,…,XN)𝐗subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑁\mathbf{X}=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{N}) as well as the randomness of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) characterized the minimax optimal excess risk (up to logarithms) for convex ISRL-DP FL in the homogeneous (i.i.d.) case:

Θ~​(1N​(1n+d​log⁡(1/δ)ε​n)),~Θ1𝑁1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\widetilde{\Theta}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right)\right), (2)

where d𝑑d is the dimension of the parameter space and ε,δ𝜀𝛿\varepsilon,\delta are the privacy parameters. For heterogeneous FL, the state-of-the-art excess risk bound is O​(1/N​n+(d​log⁡(1/δ)/(ε​n​N))4/5)𝑂1𝑁𝑛superscript𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛𝑁45O\left(1/\sqrt{Nn}+\left(\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}/(\varepsilon n\sqrt{N})\right)^{4/5}\right), assuming smoothness of the loss function (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b). Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) left the following question open:

Question 1. Can the optimal ISRL-DP excess risk in (2) for solving Problem FL be attained in the presence of heterogeneous silo data?

Contribution 1. We give a positive answer to Question 1. Moreover, we do not require smoothness of the loss function to attain the optimal rate: see Theorem 3.1.

In practical FL settings (especially cross-device settings), it can be expensive or slow for silos to communicate with the server or with each other (Kairouz et al., 2021). Thus, another important desiderata for FL algorithms is communication efficiency, which is measured by communication complexity: the number of communication rounds R𝑅R that are required to achieve excess risk α𝛼\alpha. In the homogeneous setting, the state-of-the-art communication complexity for an algorithm achieving optimal excess risk is due to Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b, Theorem D.1):

RSOTA=O~​(min⁡{N​n,N​n2​ε2d}).subscript𝑅SOTA~𝑂𝑁𝑛𝑁superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑R_{\text{SOTA}}=\widetilde{O}\left(\min\left\{Nn,\frac{Nn^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}{d}\right\}\right). (3)

Question 2. Can the optimal ISRL-DP excess risk in (2) for solving Problem FL be attained in fewer communication rounds R𝑅R, for R≪RS​O​T​Amuch-less-than𝑅subscript𝑅𝑆𝑂𝑇𝐴R\ll R_{SOTA}?

Contribution 2. We answer Question 2 positively. For smooth losses, our algorithm achieves optimal excess risk with significantly improved communication complexity:

Rsmooth=O~​(min⁡{(N​n)1/4,N1/4​n1/2​ε1/2d1/4}).subscript𝑅smooth~𝑂superscript𝑁𝑛14superscript𝑁14superscript𝑛12superscript𝜀12superscript𝑑14R_{\text{smooth}}=\widetilde{O}\left(\min\left\{(Nn)^{1/4},\frac{N^{1/4}n^{1/2}\varepsilon^{1/2}}{d^{1/4}}\right\}\right). (4)

Our communication complexity in (4) matches the non-private lower bound of Woodworth et al. (2020) in the high heterogeneity regime (Theorem 2.4), hinting at the communication-optimality of our algorithm.

For non-smooth loss functions, our communication complexity is

Rnon-smooth=O~​(min⁡{(N​n)1/2,N1/2​n​εd1/2}),subscript𝑅non-smooth~𝑂superscript𝑁𝑛12superscript𝑁12𝑛𝜀superscript𝑑12R_{\text{non-smooth}}=\widetilde{O}\left(\min\left\{(Nn)^{1/2},\frac{N^{1/2}n\varepsilon}{d^{1/2}}\right\}\right), (5)

a major improvement over the prior state-of-the-art bound in (3).

Moreover, we achieve these improved communication complexity and optimal excess risk bounds without assuming homogeneity of silo data.

When N=1𝑁1N=1 in (FL), ISRL-DP FL reduces to central DP stochastic convex optimization (SCO), which has been studied extensively (Bassily et al., 2019; Feldman et al., 2020; Asi et al., 2021; Zhang et al., 2022). In this centralized setting, communication complexity is usually referred to as iteration complexity. Even in the special case of N=1𝑁1N=1, our iteration complexity for smooth losses improves over the prior state-of-the-art result (Zhang et al., 2022).

Another important property of FL algorithms is computational efficiency, which we measure by (sub)gradient complexity: the number of stochastic (sub)gradients T𝑇T that an algorithm must compute to achieve excess risk α𝛼\alpha.

In the homogeneous case, the state-of-the-art gradient complexity for an ISRL-DP FL algorithm that attains optimal excess risk is due to Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b, Theorem D.1). For smooth losses and ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1), Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) obtained the follow gradient complexity

TSOTA=O~​(N2​min⁡{n,n2d}+N3/2​min⁡{n3/2,n2d1/2}).subscript𝑇SOTA~𝑂superscript𝑁2𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑑superscript𝑁32superscript𝑛32superscript𝑛2superscript𝑑12T_{\text{SOTA}}\!=\!\widetilde{O}\left(N^{2}\min\left\{n,\frac{n^{2}}{d}\right\}+N^{3/2}\min\left\{n^{3/2},\frac{n^{2}}{d^{1/2}}\right\}\right). (6)

Question 3. Can the optimal ISRL-DP excess risk in (2) for solving Problem FL be attained with smaller gradient complexity T≪TSOTAmuch-less-than𝑇subscript𝑇SOTAT\ll T_{\text{SOTA}}?

Contribution 3. We give a positive answer to Question 3. We provide an ISRL-DP FL algorithm with optimal excess risk and improved gradient complexity (see Theorem 2.1). When d=Θ​(n)𝑑Θ𝑛d=\Theta(n) and ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1), our gradient complexity bound simplifies to

Tsmooth=O~​(N5/4​n1/4+(N​n)9/8).subscript𝑇smooth~𝑂superscript𝑁54superscript𝑛14superscript𝑁𝑛98T_{\text{smooth}}=\widetilde{O}\left(N^{5/4}n^{1/4}+(Nn)^{9/8}\right). (7)

In Theorem 3.4, we also improve over the state-of-the-art subgradient complexity bound of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b, Theorem D.2) for non-smooth losses. Moreover, in contrast to these earlier results, we do not assume homogeneous data.

Our Algorithms and Techniques.

Our algorithms combine and extend various private optimization techniques in novel ways.

Our ISRL-DP Algorithm 1 for smooth FL builds on the ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD approach used by Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) for federated empirical risk minimization (ERM). We call this algorithm repeatedly to iteratively solve a carefully chosen sequence of regularized ERM subproblems, using the localization technique of Feldman et al. (2020). We obtain our novel optimal excess risk bounds for heterogeneous FL with an algorithmic stability (Bousquet and Elisseeff, 2002) argument. The key observation is that the stability and generalization of regularized ERM in Shalev-Shwartz et al. (2009) does not require the data to be identically distributed. By combining this observation with a bound for ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD, we obtain our excess risk bound.

It is not immediately clear that the approach just described should work, because the iterates of Accelerated MB-SGD are not necessarily stable. The instability of acceleration may explain why Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) used ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD only for ERM and not for minimizing the population risk. We overcome this obstacle with an alternative analysis that leverages the stability of regularized ERM, the convergence of ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD to an approximate minimizer of the regularized empirical loss, and localization. This argument enables us to show that our algorithm has optimal excess risk. By carefully choosing algorithmic parameters, we also obtain state-of-the-art communication and gradient complexities.

To extend our algorithm to the non-smooth case, we use two different techniques. One is Nesterov smoothing (Nesterov, 2005), which results in an algorithm with favorable communication complexity. The other approach is to replace the ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD ERM subsolver by an ISRL-DP Subgradient Method. This technique yields an algorithm with favorable (sub)gradient complexity. Third, we use randomized convolution smoothing, as in Kulkarni et al. (2021), to obtain another favorable gradient complexity bound.

1.1 Preliminaries

Differential Privacy.

Let 𝕏=𝒳n×N𝕏superscript𝒳𝑛𝑁\mathbb{X}=\mathcal{X}^{n\times N} and ρ:𝕏2→[0,∞):𝜌→superscript𝕏20\rho:\mathbb{X}^{2}\to[0,\infty) be a distance between distributed data sets. Two distributed data sets 𝐗,𝐗′∈𝕏𝐗superscript𝐗′𝕏\mathbf{X},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X} are ρ𝜌\rho-adjacent if ρ​(𝐗,𝐗′)≤1𝜌𝐗superscript𝐗′1\rho(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{X}^{\prime})\leq 1. Differential privacy (DP) prevents an adversary from distinguishing between the outputs of algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} when it is run on adjacent databases:

Definition 1.1 (Differential Privacy (Dwork et al., 2006)).

Let ε≥0,δ∈[0,1)formulae-sequence𝜀0𝛿01\varepsilon\geq 0,~{}\delta\in[0,1). A randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝕏→𝒲:𝒜→𝕏𝒲\mathcal{A}:\mathbb{X}\to\mathcal{W} is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private (DP) for all ρ𝜌\rho-adjacent data sets 𝐗,𝐗′∈𝕏𝐗superscript𝐗′𝕏\mathbf{X},\mathbf{X}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{X} and all measurable subsets S⊆𝒲𝑆𝒲S\subseteq\mathcal{W}, we have

ℙ​(𝒜​(𝐗)∈S)≤eε​ℙ​(𝒜​(𝐗′)∈S)+δ.ℙ𝒜𝐗𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀ℙ𝒜superscript𝐗′𝑆𝛿\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X})\in S)\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{X}^{\prime})\in S)+\delta. (8)
Definition 1.2 (Inter-Silo Record-Level Differential Privacy).

Let ρ:𝒳2​n→[0,∞):𝜌→superscript𝒳2𝑛0\rho:\mathcal{X}^{2n}\to[0,\infty), ρ​(Xi,Xi′):=∑j=1n𝟙{xi,j≠xi,j′}assign𝜌subscript𝑋𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑋′𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗′\rho(X_{i},X^{\prime}_{i}):=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\mathbbm{1}_{\{x_{i,j}\neq x_{i,j}^{\prime}\}}, i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N]. 2 Localized ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD for Smooth Losses

We start with the smooth case. Combining iterative localization techniques of Feldman et al. (2020); Asi et al. (2021) with the multi-stage ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b), our proposed Algorithm 1 achieves optimal excess risk and state-of-the-art communication complexity for heterogeneous FL under ISRL-DP.

We recall ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD in Algorithm 2. It is a distributed, ISRL-DP version of the AC-SA algorithm (Ghadimi and Lan, 2012). For strongly convex losses, the multi-stage implementation of ISRL-DP Accelerated MB-SGD, given in Algorithm 5 in Appendix B, offers improved excess risk (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b). Algorithm 5 is a distributed, ISRL-DP version of the multi-stage AC-SA (Ghadimi and Lan, 2013).

Building on Algorithm 5, we describe our algorithm as follows (see Algorithm 1 for pseudocode). The distributed learning process is divided into τ=⌊log2⁡n⌋𝜏subscript2𝑛\tau=\lfloor\log_{2}n\rfloor phases. In each phase i∈[τ]𝑖delimited-[]𝜏i\in[\tau], all silos work together (via communication with the central server) to iteratively solve a regularized ERM problem with ISRL-DP. The regularized ERM problem in phase i𝑖i is defined over N𝑁N local batches of data, each containing nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} disjoint samples (cf. F^i​(w)subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤\hat{F}_{i}(w) in 7). To find the approximate constrained minimizer of F^i​(w)subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤\hat{F}_{i}(w) privately, we apply Algorithm 5 for a careful choice of the number of rounds Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} and the batch size Ki∈[ni]subscript𝐾𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑖K_{i}\in[n_{i}] (cf. 8). The output wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} of phase i𝑖i affects phase i+1𝑖1i+1 in three ways: (i) regularization center used to define F^i+1subscript^𝐹𝑖1\hat{F}_{i+1}; (ii) initialization for the next call of Algorithm 5; and (iii) constraint set 𝒲i+1subscript𝒲𝑖1\mathcal{W}_{i+1}. We enforce stability (hence generalization) of our algorithm via regularization and localization: e.g., as i𝑖i increases, we increase the regularization parameter λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} to prevent wi+1subscript𝑤𝑖1w_{i+1} from moving too far away from wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}.

The following theorem captures our main results of this section: Algorithm 1 can achieve the optimal excess risk, regardless of the heterogeneity, in a communication-efficient and gradient-efficient manner.

Theorem 2.1 (Upper Bound for Smooth Losses).

Let f​(⋅,x)𝑓⋅𝑥f(\cdot,x) be β𝛽\beta-smooth and M=N𝑀𝑁M=N. Assume ε≤2​ln⁡(2/δ),δ∈(0,1)formulae-sequence𝜀22𝛿𝛿01\varepsilon\leq 2\ln(2/\delta),\delta\in(0,1). Then, there exist parameter choices such that Algorithm 1 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP and has the following excess risk

𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)=O~​(L​DN​(1n+d​log⁡(1/δ)ε​n)).𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤~𝑂𝐿𝐷𝑁1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\!\!\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})\!-\!F(w^{*})\!=\!\widetilde{O}\!\left(\frac{LD}{\sqrt{N}}\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\!+\!\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right)\!\!\right). (9)

Moreover, the communication complexity of Algorithm 1 is

O~​(β​D​N1/4L​(min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})1/2+1).~𝑂𝛽𝐷superscript𝑁14𝐿superscript𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿121\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\beta D}N^{1/4}}{\sqrt{L}}\left(\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\}\right)^{1/2}+1\right).

Assuming d=Θ​(n)𝑑Θ𝑛d=\Theta(n) and ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1), the gradient complexity of Algorithm 1 is

O~​(N5/4​n1/4​(β​D/L)1/2+N​n+(N​n)9/8​(β​D/L)1/4).~𝑂superscript𝑁54superscript𝑛14superscript𝛽𝐷𝐿12𝑁𝑛superscript𝑁𝑛98superscript𝛽𝐷𝐿14\displaystyle\widetilde{O}\left(N^{5/4}n^{1/4}(\beta D/L)^{1/2}+Nn+(Nn)^{9/8}(\beta D/L)^{1/4}\right).

For general d,n,ε𝑑𝑛𝜀d,n,\varepsilon, the gradient complexity expression is complicated, and is given in the Section C.1.

Remark 2.2 (Optimal risk in non-i.i.d private FL).

The excess risk bound in (9) matches the optimal i.i.d risk bound up to log factors (cf. Theorem 2.2 in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b)), even when silo data is arbitrarily heterogeneous across silos. To the best of our knowledge, our algorithm is the first to have this property, resolving an open question of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b). The prior state-of-the-art bound in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b, Theorem 3.1) is suboptimal by a factor of O~​((d/(ε​n​N))1/5)~𝑂superscript𝑑𝜀𝑛𝑁15\widetilde{O}((\sqrt{d}/(\varepsilon n\sqrt{N}))^{1/5}).

Remark 2.3 (Improved communication and gradient complexity).

The communication and gradient complexities of our Algorithm 1 significantly improve over the previous state-of-the-art for ISRL-DP FL: recall (3), (4), (6), and (7).

Our algorithm has state-of-the-art communication complexity, even in the simple case of N=1𝑁1N=1, where ISRL-DP FL reduces to central DP SCO. In fact, the prior state-of-the-art iteration complexity bound for DP SCO was O​((β​D/L)​min⁡{n,ε​n/d​ln⁡(1/δ)})𝑂𝛽𝐷𝐿𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿O((\beta D/L)\min\{\sqrt{n},\varepsilon n/\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}\}) (Zhang et al., 2022). By comparison, when N=1𝑁1N=1, our algorithm’s communication complexity is the square root of this bound. Note that when N=1𝑁1N=1, our algorithm is essentially the same as the algorithm of Kulkarni et al. (2021), but we do not incorporate convolution smoothing here since we are assuming smoothness of the loss.

We can also compare our gradient complexity results against the state-of-the-art central DP SCO algorithms when N=1𝑁1N=1. As an illustration, consider the interesting regime ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1) and d=Θ​(n)𝑑Θ𝑛d=\Theta(n). For smooth and convex losses, when (i) β≤O​(n​L/D)𝛽𝑂𝑛𝐿𝐷\beta\leq O(\sqrt{n}L/D), algorithms in both Feldman et al. (2020) and Zhang et al. (2022) achieve optimal risk using O~​(n)~𝑂𝑛\widetilde{O}(n) gradient complexity. For (ii) β≥Ω​(n​L/D)𝛽Ω𝑛𝐿𝐷\beta\geq\Omega(\sqrt{n}L/D), the two algorithms proposed by Feldman et al. (2020) fail to guarantee optimal risk, whereas Zhang et al. (2022, Algorithm 2) continues to attain optimal risk with gradient complexity O~​(n3/4​β​D/L)~𝑂superscript𝑛34𝛽𝐷𝐿\widetilde{O}(n^{3/4}\sqrt{\beta D/L}). By comparison with these results, for case (i), our Algorithm 1 achieves optimal risk with gradient complexity O~​(n5/4)~𝑂superscript𝑛54\widetilde{O}(n^{5/4}). For case (ii), as in Zhang et al. (2022), our Algorithm 1 continues to achieve optimal risk with gradient complexity O~​(n9/8​(β​D/L)1/4+n1/4​(β​D/L)1/2+n)~𝑂superscript𝑛98superscript𝛽𝐷𝐿14superscript𝑛14superscript𝛽𝐷𝐿12𝑛\widetilde{O}(n^{9/8}(\beta D/L)^{1/4}+n^{1/4}(\beta D/L)^{1/2}+n). Thus, our algorithm is faster than the state-of-the-art result of Zhang et al. (2022) when β​D/L≥n3/2𝛽𝐷𝐿superscript𝑛32\beta D/L\geq n^{3/2}. In the complementary parameter regime, however, the algorithm of Zhang et al. (2022) (which is not ISRL-DP) is faster. We discuss possible ways to close this gap in Section 5.

Comparison with Non-Private Communication Complexity Lower Bound.

Theorem 2.1 trivially extends to the unconstrained optimization setting in which D=‖w0−w∗‖𝐷normsubscript𝑤0superscript𝑤D=\|w_{0}-w^{*}\| for w∗∈arg​minw∈ℝd⁡F​(w)superscript𝑤subscriptargmin𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝑤w^{*}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(w). Moreover, our excess risk bound is still optimal for the unconstrained case: a matching lower bound is obtained by combining the technique for unconstrained DP lower bounds in Liu and Lu (2021) with the constrained ISRL-DP FL lower bounds of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b).

Let us compare our communication complexity upper bound against the non-private communication complexity lower bound of Woodworth et al. (2020). Define the following parameter which describes the heterogeneity of the silos at the optimum w∗=arg​minw∈ℝd⁡F​(w)superscript𝑤subscriptargmin𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝑤w^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(w):

ζ∗2=1N​∑i=1N‖∇Fi​(w∗)‖2.superscriptsubscript𝜁21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑤2\zeta_{*}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\nabla F_{i}(w^{*})\|^{2}.

The lower bound holds for the class of distributed zero-respecting algorithms (defined in Appendix F), which includes most non-private FL algorithms, such as MB-SGD, Accelerated MB-SGD, local SGD/FedAvg, and so on.

Theorem 2.4 (Communication Lower Bound (Woodworth et al., 2020)).

Fix M=N𝑀𝑁M=N and suppose 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is a distributed zero-respecting algorithm with excess risk

𝔼​F​(𝒜​(X))−F∗≲L​DN​(1n+d​ln⁡(1/δ)ε​n)less-than-or-similar-to𝔼𝐹𝒜𝑋superscript𝐹𝐿𝐷𝑁1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\mathbb{E}F(\mathcal{A}(X))-F^{*}\lesssim\frac{LD}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right)

in ≤Rabsent𝑅\leq R rounds of communications on any β𝛽\beta-smooth FL problem with heterogeneity ζ∗subscript𝜁\zeta_{*} and ‖w0−w∗‖≤Dnormsubscript𝑤0superscript𝑤𝐷\|w_{0}-w^{*}\|\leq D. Then,

R𝑅\displaystyle R ≳N1/4​(min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})1/2greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript𝑁14superscript𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿12\displaystyle\gtrsim N^{1/4}\left(\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\}\right)^{1/2}
×min⁡(β​DL,ζ∗β​L​D).absent𝛽𝐷𝐿subscript𝜁𝛽𝐿𝐷\displaystyle\;\;\;\;\times\min\left(\frac{\sqrt{\beta D}}{\sqrt{L}},\frac{\zeta_{*}}{\sqrt{\beta LD}}\right).
Remark 2.5.

Our communication complexity in Theorem 2.1 matches the lower bound on the communication cost in Theorem 2.4 when ζ∗≳β​Dgreater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscript𝜁𝛽𝐷\zeta_{*}\gtrsim\beta D (i.e., high heterogeneity).

There are several reasons why we cannot quite assert that Theorem 2.4 implies that Algorithm 1 is communication-optimal. First, the lower bound does not hold for randomized algorithms that are not zero-respecting (e.g. our ISRL-DP algorithms). However, Woodworth et al. (2020) note that the lower bound should be extendable to all randomized algorithms by using the random rotations techniques of Woodworth and Srebro (2016); Carmon et al. (2020). Second, the lower bound construction of Woodworth et al. (2020) is not L𝐿L-Lipschitz. However, we believe that their quadratic construction can be approximated by a Lipschitz function (e.g. by using an appropriate Huber function). Third, as is standard in non-private complexity lower bounds, the construction requires the dimension d𝑑d to grow with R𝑅R. This third issue seems challenging to overcome, and may require a fundamentally different proof approach. Thus, a rigorous proof of a communication complexity lower bound for ISRL-DP algorithms and Lipschitz functions is an interesting topic for future work.

Sketch of the Proof of Theorem 2.1.

We end this section with a high-level overview of the key steps needed to establish Theorem 2.1.

Proof sketch.

Privacy: We choose parameters so that each call to Algorithm 5 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP. Then, the full Algorithm 1 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP by parallel composition, since silo l𝑙l samples disjoint local batches across phases (∀l∈[N]for-all𝑙delimited-[]𝑁\forall l\in[N]).

Excess risk: Following Feldman et al. (2020); Asi et al. (2021), we start with the following error decomposition: Let w^0=w∗subscript^𝑤0superscript𝑤\hat{w}_{0}=w^{*} for analysis only, and write

𝔼​[F​(wτ)]−F​(w∗)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})]-F(w^{*}) =𝔼​[F​(wτ)−F​(w^τ)]absent𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹subscript^𝑤𝜏\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})-F(\hat{w}_{\tau})] (10)
+∑i=1τ𝔼​[F​(w^i)−F​(w^i−1)],superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖1\displaystyle+\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})-F(\hat{w}_{i-1})], (11)

where w^i=arg​minw∈𝒲⁡F^i​(w)subscript^𝑤𝑖subscriptargmin𝑤𝒲subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤\hat{w}_{i}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\hat{F}_{i}(w) for i∈[τ]𝑖delimited-[]𝜏i\in[\tau]. Then, it remains to bound (10) and (11), respectively. To this end, we first show that wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} in Algorithm 1 is close to w^isubscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}_{i} for all i∈[τ]𝑖delimited-[]𝜏i\in[\tau]. Here, we mainly leverage the excess empirical risk bound of Algorithm 5 for ERM with strongly convex and smooth loss functions. In particular, by the empirical risk bound in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b, Theorem F.1) and λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}-strongly convex of F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i}, we can show that the following bound holds for all i∈[τ]𝑖delimited-[]𝜏i\in[\tau]:

𝔼​[‖wi−w^i‖2]≤O~​(L2λi2​N⋅d​log⁡(1/δ)ni2​ε2).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖2~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖2𝑁𝑑1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2superscript𝜀2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|w_{i}-\hat{w}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}^{2}N}\cdot\frac{d\log(1/\delta)}{n_{i}^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right). (12)

We bound (10) via (12), Lipschitzness, and Jensen’s Inequality.

To bound (11), we first leverage a key observation that stability and generalization of the empirical minimizer of strongly-convex loss does not require homogeneous data. This observation that allows us to handle the non-i.i.d. case optimally. Specifically, by the stability result, we have

𝔼​[F​(w^i)−F​(w^i−1)]≲λi​𝔼​[‖w^i−1−wi−1‖2]2+L2λi​ni​M.less-than-or-similar-to𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖1subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖122superscript𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})\!-\!F(\hat{w}_{i-1})]\lesssim\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|\hat{w}_{i-1}-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}\!+\!\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}.

We obtain a bound on (11) by combining the above inequality with (12). Finally, by putting everything together and leveraging the geometrical schedule of λi,nisubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\lambda_{i},n_{i}, we obtain the final excess population risk bound. ∎

An alternative proof approach would be to try to show that Algorithm 5 is stable directly, e.g. by using the tools that Hardt et al. (2016) use for proving stability of SGD. However, this approach seems unlikely to yield the same tight bounds that we obtain, since acceleration may impede stability of the iterates. Instead, we establish our stability and generalization guarantee indirectly: We use the facts that regularized ERM is stable and that Algorithm 5 approximates regularized ERM.

3 Error-Optimal Heterogeneous ISRL-DP FL for Non-Smooth Losses

In this section, we turn to the case of non-smooth loss functions. We modify Algorithm 1 to obtain two algorithms that can handle the non-smooth case. Our algorithms are the first to achieve the optimal excess risk for heterogeneous ISRL-DP FL with non-smooth loss functions.

3.1 Error-Optimal and Communication-Efficient ISRL-DP FL for Non-Smooth Losses

Our first algorithm is based on the technique of Nesterov smoothing (Nesterov, 2005): For a non-smooth function f𝑓f, Moreau-Yosida regularization is used to approximate f𝑓f by the β𝛽\beta-smooth β𝛽\beta-Moreau envelope

fβ​(w):=minv∈𝒲⁡(f​(v)+β2​‖w−v‖2).assignsubscript𝑓𝛽𝑤subscript𝑣𝒲𝑓𝑣𝛽2superscriptnorm𝑤𝑣2f_{\beta}(w):=\min_{v\in\mathcal{W}}\left(f(v)+\frac{\beta}{2}\|w-v\|^{2}\right).

We then optimize this smooth function using our Algorithm 1. See Appendix E for details.

Theorem 3.1 (Non-smooth FL via smoothing).

Let M=N𝑀𝑁M=N. Then the combination of Algorithm 1 with Nesterov smoothing yields an (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP algorithm with optimal excess population risk as in (9). The communication complexity is

O~​(N​min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)}+1).~𝑂𝑁𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿1\displaystyle\widetilde{O}\left(\sqrt{N}\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\}+1\right).
Remark 3.2 (Optimal excess risk in non-i.i.d. private FL).

Theorem 3.1 gives the first optimal rate for non-smooth heterogeneous FL under ISRL-DP. Note that the current best result for heterogeneous FL in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) is suboptimal and holds only for the smooth case. One can combine the same smoothing technique above with the algorithm in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) to obtain a risk bound of O​(1/n​N+(d​ln⁡(1/δ)/ε​n​N)2/3)𝑂1𝑛𝑁superscript𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛𝑁23O(1/\sqrt{nN}+(\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}/{\varepsilon n\sqrt{N}})^{2/3}) for the non-smooth case, which is again suboptimal.

Remark 3.3 (Improved communication complexity).

The communication complexity bound in Theorem 3.1 improves over the previous state-of-the-art result for an algorithm achieving optimal excess risk (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b); recall (3). Moreover, the result of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) assumed i.i.d. silo data, whereas our result holds for the non-i.i.d. case.

We have omitted the gradient complexity for this smoothing approach. This is mainly because the gradient computation of fβsubscript𝑓𝛽f_{\beta} needs additional computation in the form of the prox operator. One may consider using an approximate prox operator to get a handle on the total gradient complexity as in Bassily et al. (2019). However, this approach would still introduce an additional Θ​(n3)Θsuperscript𝑛3\Theta(n^{3}) gradient complexity per step. Thus, a natural question is whether we can design a more computation-efficient algorithm for the non-smooth case — providing a motivation for our next algorithm.

3.2 Error-Optimal and Computationally Efficient ISRL-DP FL for Non-Smooth Losses

We propose another variation of Algorithm 1 that uses subgradients to handle the non-smooth case in a computationally efficient way: see Algorithm 4. Algorithm 4 follows the same structure as Algorithm 1: we iteratively solve a carefully chosen sequence of regularized ERM problems with a ISRL-DP solver and use localization. Compared to Algorithm 1 for the smooth case, Algorithm 4 does not use an accelerated solver (due to non-smoothness). Instead, we use ISRL-DP Minibatch Subgradient method (Algorithm 3) to solve the non-smooth strongly convex ERM problem in each phase of Algorithm 4. There are two key differences between our subroutine Algorithm 3 and the ISRL-DP MB-SGD of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b): (i) Instead of the gradient, a subgradient of the non-smooth objective is used in 6; (ii) A different and simpler averaging step in 11 is used for strongly convex non-smooth losses.

Theorem 3.4 (Non-smooth FL via subgradient).

Let M=N𝑀𝑁M=N. Then, there exist parameter choices such that Algorithm 4 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP and achieves the optimal excess population risk in (9). The communication complexity is

O~​(min⁡(n​N,N​ε2​n2d)+1).~𝑂𝑛𝑁𝑁superscript𝜀2superscript𝑛2𝑑1\widetilde{O}\left(\min\left(nN,\frac{N\varepsilon^{2}n^{2}}{d}\right)+1\right).

Assuming ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1), the subgradient complexity is

O~​(N​n+N2​min⁡(n,n2d)+N3/2​min⁡(n3/2,n2d)).~𝑂𝑁𝑛superscript𝑁2𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑑superscript𝑁32superscript𝑛32superscript𝑛2𝑑\displaystyle\widetilde{O}\Bigg{(}Nn+N^{2}\min\left(n,\frac{n^{2}}{d}\right)+N^{3/2}\min\left(n^{3/2},\frac{n^{2}}{\sqrt{d}}\right)\Bigg{)}.
Remark 3.5 (Improved gradient complexity).

The above subgradient complexity improves over the state-of-the-art gradient complexity (Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b) for an ISRL-DP FL algorithm with optimal excess risk. Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) apply Nesterov smoothing to ISRL-DP MB-SGD. As discussed earlier, implementing the smoothing approach is computationally costly. Moreover, the results in Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) assume i.i.d. silo data. The subgradient complexity result in Theorem 3.4 also improves over the gradient complexity of Algorithm 1 with smoothing.

An alternative approach is to use the convolutional smoothing technique (Kulkarni et al., 2021) to optimize non-smooth functions. For certain regimes, this approach improves the gradient complexity over the subgradient method, with a worse communication complexity compared to the Nesterov smoothing approach. See Appendix D for details.

Depending on the FL application, communication or computation may be more of a bottleneck. If communication efficiency is more of a priority, the smoothed version of Algorithm 1 should be used. On the other hand, if computational efficiency is more pressing, Algorithm 4 or Algorithm 6 is recommended.

4 Numerical Experiments

We validate our theoretical findings with numerical experiments on MNIST data. As shown in Figures 3 and 3, our algorithm consistently outperforms Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b). We use a similar experimental setup to Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b), as outlined below.

Task/model/data set.

We run binary logistic regression with heterogeneous MNIST data: each of the N=25𝑁25N=25 silos contains data corresponding to one odd digit class and one even digit class (e.g. (1, 0), (3, 2), etc.) and the goal is to classify each digit as odd or even. We randomly sample roughly 1/5151/5 of MNIST data to expedite the experiments. We borrow the code from Woodworth et al. (2020) to transform and preprocess MNIST data.

Preprocessing.

We preprocess MNIST data, flatten the images, and reduce the dimension to d=50𝑑50d=50 using PCA. We use an 80/20 train/test split, yielding a total of n=1734𝑛1734n=1734 training samples.

Our algorithm.

Localized ISRL-DP MB-SGD, which is a practical (non-accelerated) variant of our Algorithm 1: For simplicity and to expedite parameter search, we use vanilla MB-SGD in place of accelerated MB-SGD as our regularized ERM subsolver in our implementation of Algorithm 1.

Baseline.

We compare our algorithm against the One-pass ISRL-DP MB-SGD of Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b). Recall that Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b) did not provide theoretical guarantees for their multi-pass ISRL-DP MB-SGD with heterogeneous silos.

Hyperparameter tuning and evaluation.

We evaluate the algorithms across a range of privacy parameters ε𝜀\varepsilon and fix δ=1/n2𝛿1superscript𝑛2\delta=1/n^{2}. For each algorithm and each setting of ε𝜀\varepsilon, we search a range of step sizes η𝜂\eta.

Simulating unreliable communication.

In addition to the reliable communication setting where all silos communicate in each round M=N=25𝑀𝑁25M=N=25, we simulate unreliable communication by randomly selecting a subset of silos to communicate in each round. In each communication round, M=18𝑀18M=18 of the N=25𝑁25N=25 silos are chosen uniformly at random to communicate with the server.

Evaluation.

Each evaluation consists of 5 trials, each with different data due to random sampling. In each trial, for each parameter setting, we repeat 3 runs and choose the hyperparameters with the lowest average loss, and record the average test error as the test error. We plot the average test error and the standard deviation across trials.

As shown in the plots, in both reliable and unreliable communication settings, our localized ISRL-DP MB-SGD algorithm outperforms the baseline one-pass ISRL-DP MB-SGD algorithm across all privacy parameters. Despite being an algorithm designed to achieve theoretical guarantees, our algorithm evidently performs well in practice.

5 Concluding Remarks and Open Questions

We have studied private federated learning in the absence of a trusted server. We characterized the minimax optimal excess risk bounds for heterogeneous ISRL-DP FL, answering an open question posed by Lowy and Razaviyayn (2023b). Further, our algorithms advanced the state-of-the-art in terms of communication and computational efficiency. For smooth losses, the communication complexity of our optimal algorithm matches the non-private lower bound.

To conclude, we discuss some open problems that arise from our work. (1) A rigorous proof of a ISRL-DP communication complexity lower bound. (2) Is there an optimal ISRL-DP algorithm with O​(n​N)𝑂𝑛𝑁O(nN) gradient complexity? A promising approach may be to combine Algorithm 1 with ISRL-DP variance-reduction. (Note that the gradient-efficient variance-reduced central DP algorithm of Zhang et al. (2022) uses output perturbation, which requires a trusted server.) (3) Is it possible to achieve both optimal communication complexity and optimal gradient complexity simultaneously with a single algorithm? Even in the simpler centralized setting (N=1𝑁1N=1), this question is open. (4) What are the optimal rates for ISRL-DP FL problems beyond convex and uniformly Lipschitz loss functions?

Acknowledgements

XZ is supported in part by NSF CNS-2153220 and CNS-2312835. CG, AL, and SW supported in part by NSF CCF-2023239 and CCF-2224213 and AFOSR FA9550-21-1-0084.

Impact Statement

In this research, we advance the field of federated learning (FL) by introducing algorithms that enhance privacy and communication efficiency in settings where trust in a central server is not assumed. Our work has significant implications for industries handling sensitive data, such as healthcare and finance, by offering an improved method for leveraging collective data while safeguarding individual privacy. However, the increased algorithmic complexity of these algorithms could limit their accessibility, especially for organizations with limited resources. Additionally, while our approach reduces the risk of data leakage, it does not entirely eliminate the possibility of misuse or unintended consequences, such as reinforcing existing biases in data. Future research should focus on refining these algorithms to make them more accessible and addressing potential ethical implications. By doing so, we aim to contribute positively to the development of safe and equitable data handling practices in various sectors of society and the economy.

Appendix A Further Discussion of Related Work

DP Optimization.

There is a large and growing body of work on DP optimization. Most of this work focuses on the centralized setting, with Lipschitz convex loss functions in ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} geometry [Bassily et al., 2014, 2019, Feldman et al., 2020, Zhang et al., 2022] and ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} geometry [Asi et al., 2021, Bassily et al., 2021]. Recently, we have started to learn more about other central DP optimization settings, such as DP optimization with non-uniformly Lipschitz loss functions/heavy-tailed data [Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023a], non-convex loss functions [Gao and Wright, 2023, Lowy et al., 2024], and min-max games [Boob and Guzmán, 2023]. There has also been work on the interactions between DP and other ethical desiderata, like fairness [Lowy et al., 2023b] and robustness [Wu et al., 2023], as well as DP optimization with side access to public data [Lowy et al., 2023c]. Despite this progress, much less is known about DP distributed optimization/federated learning, particularly in the absence of a trustworthy server.

DP Federated Learning.

There have been many works attempting to ensure privacy of people’s data during the federated learning (FL) process. Some of these works have utilized user-level differential privacy [McMahan et al., 2018, Geyer et al., 2017, Levy et al., 2021], which can be practical for cross-device FL with a trusted server. Several works have also considered inter-silo record-level DP (ISRL-DP) or similar notions to ensure privacy without a trusted server [Heikkilä et al., 2020, Liu et al., 2022, Lowy and Razaviyayn, 2023b, b, Zhou and Chowdhury, 2023].

The state-of-the-art theoretical bounds for convex ISRL-DP FL are due to Lowy and Razaviyayn [2023b] which gave minimax error-optimal algorithms and lower bounds for the i.i.d. setting, and suboptimal algorithms for the heterogeneous setting. We close this gap by providing optimal algorithms for the heterogeneous setting. Additionally, we improve over the communication complexity and gradient complexity bounds in Lowy and Razaviyayn [2023b].

Remark C.2.

The Hssian of the regularizer is λi​Isubscript𝜆𝑖𝐼\lambda_{i}I.

Therefore, ri​(w)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑤r_{i}(w) is 2​L2𝐿2L-Lipschitz and λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}-smooth. It follows that F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i} is 3​L3𝐿3L-Lipschitz and (β+λi)𝛽subscript𝜆𝑖(\beta+\lambda_{i})-smooth. ∎

2. We have the following bounds that relate the private solution wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and the true solution w^isubscript^𝑤𝑖\hat{w}_{i} of F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i}.

Lemma C.4.

In each phase i𝑖i, the following bounds hold:

𝔼​[F^i​(wi)−F^i​(w^i)]=O~​(L2λi​M⋅d​ln⁡(1/δ)ε2​ni2),𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖𝑀𝑑1𝛿superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(w_{i})-\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})]=\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}M}\cdot\frac{d\ln(1/\delta)}{\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}\right), (18)
𝔼​[‖wi−w^i‖2]≤O~​(L2λi2​M⋅d​log⁡(1/δ)ni2​ε2).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖2~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖2𝑀𝑑1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2superscript𝜀2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|w_{i}-\hat{w}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}^{2}M}\cdot\frac{d\log(1/\delta)}{n_{i}^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right). (19)
Proof.

Applying Lemma B.1 to F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i}, we have

𝔼​[F^i​(wi)−F^i​(w^i)]=O~​(L2λi​M⋅d​ln⁡(1/δ)ε2​ni2).𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖𝑀𝑑1𝛿superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(w_{i})-\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})]=\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}M}\cdot\frac{d\ln(1/\delta)}{\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}\right).

By using the λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}-strong convexity, we have

λi2​𝔼​[‖wi−w^i‖2]≤𝔼​[F^i​(wi)−F^i​(w^i)].subscript𝜆𝑖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖2𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖\frac{\lambda_{i}}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|w_{i}-\hat{w}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(w_{i})-\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})].

The bound (19) follows. ∎

3. As a consequence, we have the following bound.

Lemma C.5.

Let w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in\mathcal{W}. We have

𝔼​[F​(w^i)]−F​(w)≤λi​𝔼​[‖w−wi−1‖2]2+4⋅(3​L)2λi​ni​M.𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹𝑤subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑖122⋅4superscript3𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})]-F(w)\leq\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}+\frac{4\cdot(3L)^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}.
Proof.

Applying the stability result in Lemma H.1 to F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i} with m=M​ni𝑚𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖m=Mn_{i}, which is λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}-strongly convex and 3​L3𝐿3L-Lipschitz, we have

𝔼​[F^i​(w^i)−F^i​(w)]≤4⋅(3​L)2λi​ni​M.𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤⋅4superscript3𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})-\hat{F}_{i}(w)]\leq\frac{4\cdot(3L)^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}.

It follows from the definition of F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i} that

𝔼​[F​(w^i)]−F​(w)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹𝑤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})]-F(w) =𝔼​[F^i​(w^i)]−λi​𝔼​[‖w^i−wi−1‖2]2−(F^i​(w)−λi​𝔼​[‖w−wi−1‖2]2)absent𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖122subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑖122\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})]-\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|\hat{w}_{i}-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}-\left(\hat{F}_{i}(w)-\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}\right) (20)
≤λi​𝔼​[‖w−wi−1‖2]2+𝔼​[F^i​(w^i)−F^i​(w)]absentsubscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑖122𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐹𝑖subscript^𝑤𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\leq\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}+\mathbb{E}[\hat{F}_{i}(\hat{w}_{i})-\hat{F}_{i}(w)]
≤λi​𝔼​[‖w−wi−1‖2]2+4⋅(3​L)2λi​ni​M.absentsubscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑖122⋅4superscript3𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\displaystyle\leq\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}+\frac{4\cdot(3L)^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}.

∎

Putting these results together, we now prove the theorem.

Proof of Theorem C.1.

Privacy. By the privacy guarantee of Algorithm 5 given in Lemma B.1, each phase of the algorithm is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP. Since the batches {Bi,l}i=1τsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑙𝑖1𝜏\{B_{i,l}\}_{i=1}^{\tau} are disjoint for all l∈[N]𝑙delimited-[]𝑁l\in[N], the privacy guarantee of the entire algorithm follows by parallel composition of differential privacy [McSherry, 2009].

Excess risk. Recall that we define w^0=w∗subscript^𝑤0superscript𝑤\hat{w}_{0}=w^{*}. Write

𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)=𝔼​[F​(wτ)−F​(w^τ)]+∑i=1τ𝔼​[F​(w^i)−F​(w^i−1)].𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹subscript^𝑤𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖1\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})=\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})-F(\hat{w}_{\tau})]+\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})-F(\hat{w}_{i-1})].

Since τ=⌊log2⁡n⌋𝜏subscript2𝑛\tau=\lfloor\log_{2}n\rfloor, we have nτ=Θ​(1)subscript𝑛𝜏Θ1n_{\tau}=\Theta(1) and λτ=Θ​(λ​np)subscript𝜆𝜏Θ𝜆superscript𝑛𝑝\lambda_{\tau}=\Theta(\lambda n^{p}). By (19) and Jensen’s Inequality 𝔼​Z≤𝔼​Z2𝔼𝑍𝔼superscript𝑍2\mathbb{E}Z\leq\sqrt{\mathbb{E}Z^{2}}, we bound the first term as follows:

𝔼​[F​(wτ)−F​(w^τ)]≤L​𝔼​[‖wτ−w^τ‖]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹subscript^𝑤𝜏𝐿𝔼delimited-[]normsubscript𝑤𝜏subscript^𝑤𝜏\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})-F(\hat{w}_{\tau})]\leq L\mathbb{E}\left[\|w_{\tau}-\hat{w}_{\tau}\|\right] ≤O~​(L2M​λτ​nτ⋅d​log⁡(1/δ)ε)absent~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2𝑀subscript𝜆𝜏subscript𝑛𝜏𝑑1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\sqrt{M}\lambda_{\tau}n_{\tau}}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}\right)
≤O~​(L2λ​np​M⋅d​log⁡(1/δ)ε)absent~𝑂⋅superscript𝐿2𝜆superscript𝑛𝑝𝑀𝑑1𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda n^{p}\sqrt{M}}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}\right)
≤O~​(L2LD​n​M⋅np​M)≤O~​(D​Lnp−12),absent~𝑂superscript𝐿2⋅𝐿𝐷𝑛𝑀superscript𝑛𝑝𝑀~𝑂𝐷𝐿superscript𝑛𝑝12\displaystyle\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{L^{2}}{\frac{L}{D\sqrt{nM}}\cdot n^{p}\sqrt{M}}\right)\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{DL}{n^{p-\tfrac{1}{2}}}\right),

where the last step is due to the choice of λ𝜆\lambda, per (15). Now recall p=max⁡(12​logn⁡(M)+1,3)𝑝12subscript𝑛𝑀13p=\max(\tfrac{1}{2}\log_{n}(M)+1,3). We have

np−12≥n⋅nlogn⁡(M)=n​M.superscript𝑛𝑝12⋅𝑛superscript𝑛subscript𝑛𝑀𝑛𝑀n^{p-\tfrac{1}{2}}\geq\sqrt{n\cdot n^{\log_{n}(M)}}=\sqrt{nM}. (21)

It follows that 𝔼​[F​(wτ)−F​(w^τ)]≤O~​(D​Ln​M)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹subscript^𝑤𝜏~𝑂𝐷𝐿𝑛𝑀\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})-F(\hat{w}_{\tau})]\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{DL}{\sqrt{nM}}\right).

Note that λi​ni2=Θ​(λ​n2⋅2(p−2)​i)subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2Θ⋅𝜆superscript𝑛2superscript2𝑝2𝑖\lambda_{i}n_{i}^{2}=\Theta(\lambda n^{2}\cdot 2^{(p-2)i}) and p≥3𝑝3p\geq 3. We know that λi​ni2subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2\lambda_{i}n_{i}^{2} and λi​nisubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\lambda_{i}n_{i} increase geometrically. By combining Lemma C.5 and (18), we obtain

∑i=1τ𝔼​[F​(w^i)−F​(w^i−1)]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖1\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})-F(\hat{w}_{i-1})] ≤∑i=1τ(λi​𝔼​[‖wi−1−w^i−1‖2]2+4⋅(3​L)2λi​ni​M)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑖1subscript^𝑤𝑖122⋅4superscript3𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\left(\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w_{i-1}-\hat{w}_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}+\frac{4\cdot(3L)^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}\right)
≤O~​(λ​D2+∑i=2τL2λi​ni2​M⋅d​log⁡(1/δ)ε2+∑i=1τL2λi​ni​M)absent~𝑂𝜆superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝜏⋅superscript𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2𝑀𝑑1𝛿superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscript𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\displaystyle\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\lambda D^{2}+\sum_{i=2}^{\tau}\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}^{2}M}\cdot\frac{d\log(1/\delta)}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\frac{L^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}\right)

setting λ𝜆\lambda as per (15) gives the result.

=O~​(max⁡{⌊log2⁡n⌋,βλ,𝟙{M<N}​ε2​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})absent~𝑂subscript2𝑛𝛽𝜆subscript1𝑀𝑁superscript𝜀2𝑛𝑑1𝛿\displaystyle=\widetilde{O}\left(\max\left\{\lfloor\log_{2}n\rfloor,\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\lambda}},\mathbbm{1}_{\{M<N\}}\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n}{d\ln(1/\delta)}\right\}\right)

For gradient complexity, we defer the analysis to the following section. ∎

C.1 Gradient Complexity of Algorithm 1 under Different Parameter Regimes

Theorem C.6.

When N=M𝑁𝑀N=M and the full batch Ki=nisubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖K_{i}=n_{i} is used, the gradient complexity of Algorithm 1 is

When we choose Ki<nisubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖K_{i}<n_{i}, the communication cost can be worse due to the second term of Ri=max⁡{1,β+λiλi​ln⁡(Δi​λi​M​ε2​ni2L2​d),𝟙{M​Ki<N​ni}​ε2​ni2K​d​ln⁡(1/δ)}subscript𝑅𝑖1𝛽subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscriptΔ𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖𝑀superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2superscript𝐿2𝑑subscript1𝑀subscript𝐾𝑖𝑁subscript𝑛𝑖superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2𝐾𝑑1𝛿R_{i}=\max\left\{1,\sqrt{\frac{\beta+\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{i}}}\ln\left(\frac{\Delta_{i}\lambda_{i}M\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}{L^{2}d}\right),\mathbbm{1}_{\{MK_{i}<Nn_{i}\}}\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}{Kd\ln(1/\delta)}\right\}. Now we relax the assumption M=N𝑀𝑁M=N, and discuss general results.

In particular, when d=Θ​(n)𝑑Θ𝑛d=\Theta(n), the gradient complexity is M5/4​n1/4+(M​n)9/8superscript𝑀54superscript𝑛14superscript𝑀𝑛98M^{5/4}n^{1/4}+(Mn)^{9/8}, or more precisely,

Proof.

The bound  (23) is an immediate consequence of Theorem 2.1.

Since terms in the sum decrease geometrically, we only need to consider the first term where i=1𝑖1i=1. For simplicity, we drop the index i𝑖i.

We write R=max⁡(R′,R′′)+1𝑅superscript𝑅′superscript𝑅′′1R=\max(R^{\prime},R^{\prime\prime})+1, where we let R′=Q⋅(min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})1/2superscript𝑅′⋅𝑄superscript𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿12R^{\prime}=Q\cdot\left(\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\}\right)^{1/2}, R′′=ε2​n2K​d​ln⁡(1/δ)superscript𝑅′′superscript𝜀2superscript𝑛2𝐾𝑑1𝛿R^{\prime\prime}=\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n^{2}}{Kd\ln(1/\delta)}, and Q:=β​D​M1/4/Lassign𝑄𝛽𝐷superscript𝑀14𝐿Q:=\sqrt{\beta D}M^{1/4}/\sqrt{L}. Appendix D Optimize Non-Smooth Losses via Convolutional Smoothing

D.1 Preliminaries for Convolutional Smoothing

We first provide a brief overview of convolutional smoothing and its key properties. For simplicity, let 𝒰ssubscript𝒰𝑠\mathcal{U}_{s} denote the uniform distribution over the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} ball of radius s𝑠s.

Definition D.1 (Convolutional Smoothing).

For ERM with convex loss f𝑓f, that is F^​(w)=1n​∑i=1nf​(w,xi)^𝐹𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑓𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖\hat{F}(w)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(w,x_{i}). We define the convolutional smoother of f𝑓f with radius s𝑠s as f~s:=𝔼v∼𝒰s​f​(w+v,xi)assignsubscript~𝑓𝑠subscript𝔼similar-to𝑣subscript𝒰𝑠𝑓𝑤𝑣subscript𝑥𝑖\tilde{f}_{s}:=\mathbb{E}_{v\sim\mathcal{U}_{s}}f(w+v,x_{i}). Then the ERM smoother is defined accordingly, as follows, F^s​(w)=1n​∑i=1n𝔼v∼𝒰s​f​(w+v,xi)subscript^𝐹𝑠𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑣subscript𝒰𝑠𝑓𝑤𝑣subscript𝑥𝑖\hat{F}_{s}(w)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{v\sim\mathcal{U}_{s}}f(w+v,x_{i}).

We have the following properties of the smoother F^nssubscript^𝐹subscript𝑛𝑠\hat{F}_{n_{s}} [Kulkarni et al., 2021]:

Lemma D.2.

Suppose {f​(⋅,x)}x∈Ξsubscript𝑓⋅𝑥𝑥Ξ\{f(\cdot,x)\}_{x\in\Xi} is convex and L𝐿L-Lipschitz over 𝒦+B2​(0,s)𝒦subscript𝐵20𝑠\mathcal{K}+B_{2}(0,s). For w∈𝒦,F~s​(w)𝑤𝒦subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤w\in\mathcal{K},\tilde{F}_{s}(w) has following properties:

  1. 1.

    F^​(w)≤F~s​(w)≤F^​(w)+L​s^𝐹𝑤subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤^𝐹𝑤𝐿𝑠\widehat{F}(w)\leq\tilde{F}_{s}(w)\leq\widehat{F}(w)+Ls;

  2. 2.

    F~s​(w)subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤\tilde{F}_{s}(w) is L-Lipschitz;

  3. 3.

    F~s​(w)subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤\tilde{F}_{s}(w) is L​dr𝐿𝑑𝑟\frac{L\sqrt{d}}{r}-Smooth;

  4. 4.

    For random variables v∼𝒰ssimilar-to𝑣subscript𝒰𝑠v\sim\mathcal{U}_{s} and x𝑥x uniformly from {1,2,…,n}12…𝑛\{1,2,\dots,n\}, one has

    𝔼​[∇f​(w+v,x)]=∇F~s​(w)𝔼delimited-[]∇𝑓𝑤𝑣𝑥∇subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(w+v,x)]=\nabla\tilde{F}_{s}(w)

    and

    𝔼​[‖∇F~s​(w)−∇f​(w+v,x)‖22]≤L2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤∇𝑓𝑤𝑣𝑥22superscript𝐿2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla\tilde{F}_{s}(w)-\nabla f(w+v,x)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq L^{2}.
Definition D.3 (Poisson Sampling for Convolutional Smoothing).

Since the smoother takes the form of an expectation, we can (independently) sample vi​∼iid​𝒰ssubscript𝑣𝑖iidsimilar-tosubscript𝒰𝑠v_{i}\overset{\mathrm{iid}}{\sim}\mathcal{U}_{s}, and compute ∇f​(w+vi,xi)∇𝑓𝑤subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\nabla f(w+v_{i},x_{i}) for an estimate of the gradient of f~s​(w,xi)subscript~𝑓𝑠𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖\tilde{f}_{s}(w,x_{i}). Similar calculation can be done for stochastic gradient. Let K𝐾K denote the batch size (in expectation). With Poisson sampling of a rate p=K/n𝑝𝐾𝑛p=K/n, we compute an estimate of the stochastic gradient of the ERM smoother

g^=1K​∑i=1nZi​∇f​(w+vi,xi),^𝑔1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑍𝑖∇𝑓𝑤subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\hat{g}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}\nabla f(w+v_{i},x_{i}), (25)

where Zi​∼iid​B​e​r​n​o​u​l​l​i​(p)subscript𝑍𝑖iidsimilar-to𝐵𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖𝑝Z_{i}\overset{\mathrm{iid}}{\sim}Bernoulli(p) and vi​∼iid​𝒰ssubscript𝑣𝑖iidsimilar-tosubscript𝒰𝑠v_{i}\overset{\mathrm{iid}}{\sim}\mathcal{U}_{s}. Each sample xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is included in the sum independently with probability p𝑝p.

Similar to the case for the regular stochstic gradient, we can obtain a O​(L2/m)𝑂superscript𝐿2𝑚O(L^{2}/m) bound for the variance of the estimate of the smoother, proved as follows.

Theorem D.4.

With Poisson sampling of a rate p=K/n𝑝𝐾𝑛p=K/n, let g^^𝑔\hat{g} denote the estimate of the above ERM smoother (25). Then g^^𝑔\hat{g} is an unbiased estimator of ∇F^ns​(w)∇subscript^𝐹subscript𝑛𝑠𝑤\nabla\hat{F}_{n_{s}}(w), and the variance of the estimate is 4​L2/K4superscript𝐿2𝐾4L^{2}/K.

Proof.

By boundedness of ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f, we can interchange the gradient and the expectation. We have 𝔼​[∇f​(w+vi,xi)]=∇𝔼vi∼𝒰s​f​(w+vi,xi)=f~s𝔼delimited-[]∇𝑓𝑤subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖∇subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠𝑓𝑤subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript~𝑓𝑠\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(w+v_{i},x_{i})]=\nabla\mathbb{E}_{v_{i}\sim\mathcal{U}_{s}}f(w+v_{i},x_{i})=\tilde{f}_{s}. Therefore, by linearity of expectation, we have

𝔼​[g^]=1K​∑i=1n𝔼​[Zi​∇f​(w+vi,xi)]=∇F~s​(w).𝔼delimited-[]^𝑔1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖∇𝑓𝑤subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖∇subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑤\mathbb{E}[\hat{g}]=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{i}\nabla f(w+v_{i},x_{i})\right]=\nabla\tilde{F}_{s}(w).

The variance of the estimate is

D.2 Algorithm and Analysis

For nonsmooth loss, we apply Algorithm 1 to the convolutional smoother with radius s𝑠s, where s𝑠s is to be determined. We describe the algorithm in Algorithm 6 and the subroutine in Algorithm 7. The changes compared to Algorithm 1 are listed below.

In the main algorithm, f𝑓f is replaced by the smoother fssubscript𝑓𝑠f_{s}. For the subroutine call in Line 7, we modify Algorithm 2 as follows. Let λ2​‖w−w0‖2𝜆2superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤02\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w-w_{0}\|^{2} be the regularizer applied for the subroutine call.

  • •

    We change the subsampling regime to Poisson sampling with rate p=K/n𝑝𝐾𝑛p=K/n in line 5. For silo i𝑖i, we sample Zi,j​∼iid​Bernoulli​(p)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑗iidsimilar-toBernoulli𝑝Z_{i,j}\overset{\mathrm{iid}}{\sim}\mathrm{Bernoulli}(p) for j∈[n]𝑗delimited-[]𝑛j\in[n] and include xi,jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{i,j} in the sum with probability p𝑝p. 3. As a consequence, we can reuse Lemma C.5, restated below.

Lemma D.9.

Let w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in\mathcal{W}. We have

𝔼​[F​(w^i)]−F​(w)≤λi​𝔼​[‖w−wi−1‖2]2+4⋅(3​L)2λi​ni​M.𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹𝑤subscript𝜆𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑤subscript𝑤𝑖122⋅4superscript3𝐿2subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑀\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})]-F(w)\leq\frac{\lambda_{i}\mathbb{E}[\|w-w_{i-1}\|^{2}]}{2}+\frac{4\cdot(3L)^{2}}{\lambda_{i}n_{i}M}.

Putting these results together, we now prove the theorem.

Proof.

We note that the proof is essentially the same as that in Appendix C.

Privacy. Note that using Poisson sampling does not change the privacy analysis (up to some constant factors). By our choice of σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}, each phase of the algorithm is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP. Since the batches {Bi,l}i=1τsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑙𝑖1𝜏\{B_{i,l}\}_{i=1}^{\tau} are disjoint for all l∈[M]𝑙delimited-[]𝑀l\in[M], the privacy guarantee of the entire algorithm follows from parallel composition.

Excess risk. Given the lemmas introduced above, by the identical reasoning as in Appendix C, we have the following excess risk bound for the smoother,

𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)≤O~​(L​DM​(1n+d​log⁡(1/δ)ε​n)).𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤~𝑂𝐿𝐷𝑀1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})\leq\widetilde{O}\left(\frac{LD}{\sqrt{M}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right)\right).

By Lemma D.2, we can relate this to the true loss F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} as follows

𝔼​F0​(wτ)−F0​(w∗)≤𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)+L​s.𝔼subscript𝐹0subscript𝑤𝜏subscript𝐹0superscript𝑤𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤𝐿𝑠\mathbb{E}F_{0}(w_{\tau})-F_{0}(w^{*})\leq\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})+Ls.

The bound then follows from our choice of s𝑠s.

Complexity. When we use the full batch in each round, that is, when Ki=nisubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖K_{i}=n_{i}, hiding logarithmic factors, communication complexity is

∑i=1τRisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝑅𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}R_{i} =∑i=1τmax⁡{1,β+λiλi​ln⁡(Δ​λi​M​ε2​ni2L2​d),ε2​ni2ni​d​ln⁡(1/δ)}absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏1𝛽subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖Δsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑀superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2superscript𝐿2𝑑superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2subscript𝑛𝑖𝑑1𝛿\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\max\left\{1,\sqrt{\frac{\beta+\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{i}}}\ln\left(\frac{\Delta\lambda_{i}M\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}{L^{2}d}\right),\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n_{i}^{2}}{n_{i}d\ln(1/\delta)}\right\} (33)
=O~​(max⁡{⌊log2⁡n⌋,βλ,ε2​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})absent~𝑂subscript2𝑛𝛽𝜆superscript𝜀2𝑛𝑑1𝛿\displaystyle=\widetilde{O}\left(\max\left\{\lfloor\log_{2}n\rfloor,\sqrt{\frac{\beta}{\lambda}},\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n}{d\ln(1/\delta)}\right\}\right)

where in the last step is due to our choice of β=L​d/s𝛽𝐿𝑑𝑠\beta=L\sqrt{d}/s and λ𝜆\lambda.

For gradient complexity, we can follow the same analysis in Section C.1 except that due to Poisson sampling our gradient complexity will be in expectation, instead of deterministic. We only consider the case when d=Θ​(n)𝑑Θ𝑛d=\Theta(n) and ε=Θ​(1)𝜀Θ1\varepsilon=\Theta(1) here to make it simple. Keep terms involving M𝑀M, n𝑛n only and drop O~~𝑂\widetilde{O} for simplicity. We have s=Dn​M𝑠𝐷𝑛𝑀s=\frac{D}{\sqrt{nM}}, β=L​d/s=n​L​MD𝛽𝐿𝑑𝑠𝑛𝐿𝑀𝐷\beta=L\sqrt{d}/s=\frac{nL\sqrt{M}}{D}.

Plugging β𝛽\beta into Equation 24, we obtain the gradient complexity of O~​(M3/2​n3/4+M5/4​n11/8)~𝑂superscript𝑀32superscript𝑛34superscript𝑀54superscript𝑛118\widetilde{O}\left(M^{3/2}n^{3/4}+M^{5/4}n^{11/8}\right).

Appendix E Precise Statement and Proof of Theorem 3.1

Lemma E.1.

[Nesterov, 2005] Let f:𝒲→ℝd:𝑓→𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑f:\mathcal{W}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} be convex and L𝐿L-Lipschitz and β>0𝛽0\beta>0. Then the β𝛽\beta-Moreau envelope fβ​(w):=minv∈𝒲⁡(f​(v)+β2​‖w−v‖2)assignsubscript𝑓𝛽𝑤subscript𝑣𝒲𝑓𝑣𝛽2superscriptnorm𝑤𝑣2f_{\beta}(w):=\min_{v\in\mathcal{W}}\left(f(v)+\frac{\beta}{2}\|w-v\|^{2}\right) satisfies:
(1) fβsubscript𝑓𝛽f_{\beta} is convex, 2​L2𝐿2L-Lipschitz, and β𝛽\beta-smooth;
(2) ∀w∈𝒲for-all𝑤𝒲\forall w\in\mathcal{W}, fβ​(w)≤f​(w)≤fβ​(w)+L22​βsubscript𝑓𝛽𝑤𝑓𝑤subscript𝑓𝛽𝑤superscript𝐿22𝛽f_{\beta}(w)\leq f(w)\leq f_{\beta}(w)+\frac{L^{2}}{2\beta};
(3) ∀w∈𝒲for-all𝑤𝒲\forall w\in\mathcal{W}, ∇fβ​(w)=β​(w−proxf/β​(w))∇subscript𝑓𝛽𝑤𝛽𝑤subscriptprox𝑓𝛽𝑤\nabla f_{\beta}(w)=\beta(w-\mathrm{prox}_{f/\beta}(w));
where the prox operator of f:𝒲→ℝd:𝑓→𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑f:\mathcal{W}\to\mathbbm{R}^{d} is defined as proxf​(w):=arg​minv∈𝒲⁡(f​(v)+12​∥w−v∥2)assignsubscriptprox𝑓𝑤subscriptargmin𝑣𝒲𝑓𝑣12superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑤𝑣2\mathrm{prox}_{f}(w):=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{v\in\mathcal{W}}\left(f(v)+\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert w-v\right\rVert^{2}\right).

Our algorithm for non-smooth functions uses Lemma E.1 and Algorithm 1 as follows: First, property (1) above allows us to apply Algorithm 1 to optimize fβsubscript𝑓𝛽f_{\beta} and obtain an excess population risk bound for fβsubscript𝑓𝛽f_{\beta}, via Theorem 2.1. Inside Algorithm 1, we will use property (3) to compute the gradient of fβsubscript𝑓𝛽f_{\beta}. Then, property (2) enables us to extend the excess risk guarantee to the true function f𝑓f, for a proper choice of β𝛽\beta.

Theorem E.2 (Precise Statement of Theorem 3.1).

Let ε≤2​ln⁡(2/δ)𝜀22𝛿\varepsilon\leq 2\ln(2/\delta), δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1). There exist choices of β𝛽\beta such that running Algorithm 1 with fβ​(w,x):=minv∈𝒲⁡(f​(v,x)+β2​‖w−v‖2)assignsubscript𝑓𝛽𝑤𝑥subscript𝑣𝒲𝑓𝑣𝑥𝛽2superscriptnorm𝑤𝑣2f_{\beta}(w,x):=\min_{v\in\mathcal{W}}\left(f(v,x)+\frac{\beta}{2}\|w-v\|^{2}\right) yields an (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP algorithm with optimal excess population risk as in (16). O~​(max⁡{1,M​min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)},𝟙{M<N}​ε2​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)}).~𝑂1𝑀𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿subscript1𝑀𝑁superscript𝜀2𝑛𝑑1𝛿\widetilde{O}\left(\max\left\{1,\sqrt{M}\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\},\mathbbm{1}_{\{M<N\}}\frac{\varepsilon^{2}n}{d\ln(1/\delta)}\right\}\right).
Proof.

Privacy. For any given β𝛽\beta, the privacy guarantee is immediate since we have already showed that Algorithm 1 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP.

Excess risk. By Lemma E.1 part 2, we have

𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)≤𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)+L22​β.𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤superscript𝐿22𝛽\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})\leq\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})+\frac{L^{2}}{2\beta}.

It suffices to choose β=L​MD​min⁡{n,ε​nd​log⁡(1/δ)}𝛽𝐿𝑀𝐷𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿\beta=\frac{L\sqrt{M}}{D}\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}\right\}.

Communication complexity. The result follows by plugging in our choice of β𝛽\beta into (17).

∎

Appendix F More Details on the Communication Complexity Lower Bound (Theorem 2.4)

We begin with a definition [Woodworth et al., 2020]:

Definition F.1 (Distributed Zero-Respecting Algorithm).

For v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, let supp​(v):={j∈[d]:vj≠0}assignsupp𝑣conditional-set𝑗delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑣𝑗0\text{supp}(v):=\{j\in[d]:v_{j}\neq 0\}. Denote the random seed of silo m𝑚m’s gradient oracle in round t𝑡t by ztmsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡𝑚z_{t}^{m}. An optimization algorithm is distributed zero-respecting with respect to f𝑓f if for all t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 and m∈[N]𝑚delimited-[]𝑁m\in[N], the t𝑡t-th query on silo m𝑚m, wtmsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑚w_{t}^{m} satisfies

supp​(wtm)⊆⋃s<tsupp​(∇f​(wsm,zsm))∪⋃m′≠m⋃s≤πm​(t,m′)supp​(∇f​(wsm′,zsm′)),suppsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑚subscript𝑠𝑡supp∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑠𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝑚subscript𝑠subscript𝜋𝑚𝑡superscript𝑚′supp∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑠superscript𝑚′superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑠superscript𝑚′\text{supp}(w_{t}^{m})\subseteq\bigcup_{s<t}\text{supp}(\nabla f(w_{s}^{m},z_{s}^{m}))\cup\bigcup_{m^{\prime}\neq m}\bigcup_{s\leq\pi_{m}(t,m^{\prime})}\text{supp}(\nabla f(w_{s}^{m^{\prime}},z_{s}^{m^{\prime}})),

where πm​(t,m′)subscript𝜋𝑚𝑡superscript𝑚′\pi_{m}(t,m^{\prime}) is the most recent time before t𝑡t when silos m𝑚m and m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} communicated with each other.

Theorem F.2 (Re-statement of Theorem 2.4).

Fix M=N𝑀𝑁M=N and suppose 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is a distributed zero-respecting algorithm with excess risk

𝔼​F​(𝒜​(X))−F∗≲L​DN​(1n+d​ln⁡(1/δ)ε​n)less-than-or-similar-to𝔼𝐹𝒜𝑋superscript𝐹𝐿𝐷𝑁1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\mathbb{E}F(\mathcal{A}(X))-F^{*}\lesssim\frac{LD}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right)

in ≤Rabsent𝑅\leq R rounds of communications on any β𝛽\beta-smooth FL problem with heterogeneity ζ∗subscript𝜁\zeta_{*} and ‖w0−w∗‖≤Dnormsubscript𝑤0superscript𝑤𝐷\|w_{0}-w^{*}\|\leq D. Then,

R𝑅\displaystyle R ≳N1/4​(min⁡{n,ε​nd​ln⁡(1/δ)})1/2×min⁡(β​DL,ζ∗β​L​D).greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript𝑁14superscript𝑛𝜀𝑛𝑑1𝛿12𝛽𝐷𝐿subscript𝜁𝛽𝐿𝐷\displaystyle\gtrsim N^{1/4}\left(\min\left\{\sqrt{n},\frac{\varepsilon n}{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}\right\}\right)^{1/2}\times\min\left(\frac{\sqrt{\beta D}}{\sqrt{L}},\frac{\zeta_{*}}{\sqrt{\beta LD}}\right).
Proof.

Denote the worst-case excess risk of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} by

α:=𝔼​F​(𝒜​(X))−F∗.assign𝛼𝔼𝐹𝒜𝑋superscript𝐹\alpha:=\mathbb{E}F(\mathcal{A}(X))-F^{*}.

Now, Woodworth et al. [2020, Theorem 4] implies that any zero-respecting algorithm has

R≳min⁡{ζ∗β​α,D​βα}.greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑅subscript𝜁𝛽𝛼𝐷𝛽𝛼\displaystyle R\gtrsim\min\left\{\frac{\zeta_{*}}{\sqrt{\beta\alpha}},\frac{D\sqrt{\beta}}{\sqrt{\alpha}}\right\}.

Plugging in α=L​DN​(1n+d​ln⁡(1/δ)ε​n)𝛼𝐿𝐷𝑁1𝑛𝑑1𝛿𝜀𝑛\alpha=\frac{LD}{\sqrt{N}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}{\varepsilon n}\right) proves the lower bound. ∎

[Bubeck et al., 2015, Theorem 6.2] Let g𝑔g be λ𝜆\lambda-strongly convex, and assume that the stochastic subgradient oracle returns a stochastic subgradient g~​(w)~𝑔𝑤\widetilde{g}(w) such that 𝔼​g~​(w)∈∂g​(w)𝔼~𝑔𝑤𝑔𝑤\mathbb{E}\widetilde{g}(w)\in\partial g(w) and 𝔼​‖g~​(w)‖22≤B2𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm~𝑔𝑤22superscript𝐵2\mathbb{E}\|\widetilde{g}(w)\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}. 𝔼​g​(∑r=1R2​rR​(R+1)​wr)−g​(w∗)≤2​B2λ​(R+1).𝔼𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅2𝑟𝑅𝑅1subscript𝑤𝑟𝑔superscript𝑤2superscript𝐵2𝜆𝑅1\mathbb{E}g\left(\sum_{r=1}^{R}\frac{2r}{R(R+1)}w_{r}\right)-g\left(w^{*}\right)\leq\frac{2B^{2}}{\lambda(R+1)}. (35)

As a consequence, we have the following result:

Lemma G.3.

Proof.

Given our choice of step sizes in Algorithm 4, we can verify the assumptions in Lemma G.2 are met for F^isubscript^𝐹𝑖\hat{F}_{i}. Now we are ready to prove the theorem.

Proof of Theorem G.1.

Privacy. The privacy analysis of Lowy and Razaviyayn [2023b, Theorem D.1] for ISRL-DP MB-SGD holds verbatim in the nonsmooth case when we replace subgradients by gradients: the only property of f​(⋅,x)𝑓⋅𝑥f(\cdot,x) that is used in the proof is Lipschitz continuity. Thus, Algorithm 3 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP if the noise variance is σ2≥256​L2​R​ln⁡(2.5​R/δ)​ln⁡(2/δ)ε2​n2superscript𝜎2256superscript𝐿2𝑅2.5𝑅𝛿2𝛿superscript𝜀2superscript𝑛2\sigma^{2}\geq\frac{256L^{2}R\ln(2.5R/\delta)\ln(2/\delta)}{\varepsilon^{2}n^{2}}. By our choice of σi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{i}^{2}, we see that phase i𝑖i of Algorithm 4 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP on data {Bi,l}l=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑙𝑙1𝑁\{B_{i,l}\}_{l=1}^{N}. Since the batches {Bi,l}i=1τsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑙𝑖1𝜏\{B_{i,l}\}_{i=1}^{\tau} are disjoint for all l∈[N]𝑙delimited-[]𝑁l\in[N], the full Algorithm 4 is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-ISRL-DP by parallel composition [McSherry, 2009].

Excess Risk. Define w^0=w∗subscript^𝑤0superscript𝑤\hat{w}_{0}=w^{*} and write

𝔼​F​(wτ)−F​(w∗)=𝔼​[F​(wτ)−F​(w^τ)]+∑i=1τ𝔼​[F​(w^i)−F​(w^i−1)].𝔼𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹superscript𝑤𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝜏𝐹subscript^𝑤𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖𝐹subscript^𝑤𝑖1\mathbb{E}F(w_{\tau})-F(w^{*})=\mathbb{E}[F(w_{\tau})-F(\hat{w}_{\tau})]+\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{w}_{i})-F(\hat{w}_{i-1})].

Since τ=⌊log2⁡n⌋𝜏subscript2𝑛\tau=\lfloor\log_{2}n\rfloor, we have nτ=Θ​(1)subscript𝑛𝜏Θ1n_{\tau}=\Theta(1) and ητ=η​Θ​(n−p)subscript𝜂𝜏𝜂Θsuperscript𝑛𝑝\eta_{\tau}=\eta\Theta(n^{-p}). By (37) and Jensen’s Inequality 𝔼​Z≤𝔼​Z2𝔼𝑍𝔼superscript𝑍2\mathbb{E}Z\leq\sqrt{\mathbb{E}Z^{2}}, we bound the first term as follows

Plugging in the choice of η𝜂\eta per (34) gives the desired excess risk.

∎

Appendix H A Stability Result

In order to bound the excess risk of the function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}, we require the following generalization of Theorem 6 from Shalev-Shwartz et al. [2009] which provides a stability result.

Lemma H.1.

Let g​(w,x),w∈𝒲𝑔𝑤𝑥𝑤𝒲g(w,x),\,w\in\mathcal{W} be λ𝜆\lambda-strongly convex and L𝐿L-Lipschitz in w𝑤w for all x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in\mathcal{X}. Let X=(x1,x2,…,xm)𝑋subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑚X=(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{m}) be a set of m𝑚m independent samples such that xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is sampled from their corresponding distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} for i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]. We write X∼𝒟similar-to𝑋𝒟X\sim\mathcal{D} for short.

Let G^​(w)=1m​∑i=1mg​(w,xi)^𝐺𝑤1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝑔𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖\hat{G}(w)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}g(w,x_{i}) and let w^=arg​minw∈𝒲⁡G^​(w)^𝑤subscriptargmin𝑤𝒲^𝐺𝑤\hat{w}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\hat{G}(w) be the empirical minimizer.
